KBCb7s3J.title: Embedding multi-dimensional meshes into twisted cubes
KBCb7s3J.abstract: The twisted cube is an important variant of the most popular hypercube network for parallel processing. In this paper, we consider the problem of embedding multi-dimensional meshes into twisted cubes in a systematic way. We present a recursive method for embedding a family of disjoint multi-dimensional meshes into a twisted cube with dilation 1 and expansion 1. We also prove that a single multi-dimensional mesh can be embedded into a twisted cube with dilation 2 and expansion 1. Our work extends some previously known results.

79XicOq4.title: A lower bound on the size of k-neighborhood in generalized cubes
79XicOq4.abstract: The determination of the minimum size of a k -neighborhood (i.e., a neighborhood of a set of k nodes) in a given graph is essential in the analysis of diagnosability and fault tolerance of multicomputer systems. The generalized cubes include the hypercube and most hypercube variants as special cases. In this paper, we present a lower bound on the size of a k -neighborhood in n -dimensional generalized cubes, where 2 n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 n − 2. This lower bound is tight in that it is met by the n -dimensional hypercube. Our result is an extension of two previously known results. Keywords Interconnection network Hypercube Generalized cube k -neighborhood 1 Introduction The hypercube structure has long been adopted as the topology of interconnection networks in multicomputer systems [12] . The hypercube, however, does not enjoy the smallest diameter for its resources, which implies it may suffer from longer communication delay. To achieve smaller diameter with the same numbers of nodes and links, a number of hypercube variants were proposed [2,4,6,7,14,20] . As a generalization of hypercube networks, the hypercube-like networks have received considerable attention [5,8,11,15,17] . Park and Chwa [13] and Fan and Lin [9] studied a special class of hypercube-like networks named as the BC graphs , which include most hypercube variants [2,4,6,7,14,20] as special cases. In this paper, we referred to the BC graphs as the generalized cubes to stress their similarity to hypercube. In this paper, we consider the following problem: Minimum neighborhood problem (MNP): Let θ G ( k ) denote the minimum size of a k -neighborhood (i.e, a neighborhood of a set of k nodes) in graph G . Determine θ G ( k ). The MNP is not only of interest in its own right, but the obtained result is useful in system-level fault diagnosis [3,9,11,16] and in the analysis of fault tolerance of interconnection networks [18,19] . For the n -dimensional hypercube Q n , Somani and Peleg [16] showed that, for 1 ⩽ k ⩽ n + 1, θ Q n ( k ) = - 1 2 k 2 + ( n - 1 2 ) k + 1 . For any n -dimensional generalized cube G , Fan and Lin [9] found that, for 1 ⩽ k ⩽ n + 1, θ G ( k ) ⩾ - 1 2 k 2 + ( n - 1 2 ) k + 1 . Recently, Yang et al. [22] reported that, for any n -dimensional generalized cube G and n + 2 ⩽ k ⩽ 2 n , θ G ( k ) ⩾ - 1 2 k 2 + ( 2 n - 3 2 ) k - n 2 + 2 . For other related work the reader is referred to Refs. [1,21] . This paper addresses the MNP for n -dimensional generalized cubes. The main contribution of this paper is to prove that, for any n -dimensional generalized cube G and 2 n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 n − 2, θ G ( k ) ⩾ - 1 2 k 2 + 3 n - 7 2 k - 3 n 2 + 4 n + 2 . This inequality is optimal in that the hypercube meets this bound. Clearly, our result is an extension of the aforementioned two results. As a byproduct, our result applies to various hypercube variants, including the twisted cube [2] , the crossed cube [7] , the Möbius cube [6] , and the locally twisted cube [20] . The remaining materials are organized in this fashion: Preliminary knowledge is provided in Section 2 . The main result is formulated and proved in Section 3 . Some remarks are made in Section 4 . 2 Preliminaries In this paper, we use a graph G = ( V ( G ), E ( G )) to represent an interconnection network, where the nodes and edges represent the processors and communication links, respectively. For a set S of nodes in graph G , let N G ( S ) = { v ∈ V ( G ) − S : there is u ∈ S such that ( u , v ) ∈ E ( G )}, N G [ S ] = N G ( S ) ∪ S . For our purpose, let us introduce the following notation: θ G ( k ) = min { | N G ( S ) | : S is a set of k nodes in graph G } . An n -dimensional hypercube, denoted Q n , is a graph on 2 n nodes in which the nodes can be one-to-one labeled with binary sequences of length n so that two nodes are adjacent if and only if their labels differ in exactly one bit position. For other fundamental graph-theoretic terminology the reader is referred to Ref. [10] . Definition 2.1 [9,13] An n -dimensional generalized cube is defined recursively in the following fashion: (1) A one-dimensional generalized cube is a graph on a single node. (2) For n ⩾ 2, an n -dimensional generalized cube G is built from two disjoint ( n − 1)-dimensional generalized cubes G 1 and G 2 by adding a set of edges M ϕ = {( u , ϕ ( u )) : u ∈ V ( G 1 )}, where ϕ is a bijective mapping from V ( G 1 ) to V ( G 2 ). A generalized cube G so constructed is denoted by G = ( G 1 , G 2 ; M ϕ ). For an edge ( u , v ) ∈ M ϕ , u is called as the ϕ -neighbor of v , and vice versa. In the sense of isomorphism, the length-4 cycle is the unique two-dimensional generalized cube. In the sense of isomorphism, there are only two three-dimensional generalized cubes, which are shown in Fig. 2.1 . Fig. 2.2 shows five typical four-dimensional generalized cubes. In order to estimate θ G ( k ) for n -dimensional generalized cubes, three families of quadratic functions, { p n ( x )} n ⩾1 , { q n ( x )} n ⩾1 and { r n ( x )} n ⩾1 are necessary, which are defined as p n ( x ) = - 1 2 x 2 + n - 1 2 x + 1 , q n ( x ) = - 1 2 x 2 + 2 n - 3 2 x - n 2 + 2 , r n ( x ) = - 1 2 x 2 + 3 n - 7 2 x - 3 n 2 + 4 n + 2 . Lemma 2.1 Lemma 4 in [9] , Lemma 5 in [16] Let G be an n-dimensional generalized cube. Then θ G (k) ⩾ p n (k) for 1 ⩽ k ⩽ n + 1. Moreover, this inequality is optimal in that θ Q n ( k ) = p n ( k ) for 1 ⩽ k ⩽ n + 1. Lemma 2.2 Theorem 3.1 in [22] Let G be an n-dimensional generalized cube. Then θ G (k) ⩾ q n (k) for n + 2 ⩽ k ⩽ 2n. Moreover, this inequality is optimal in that θ Q n ( k ) = q n ( k ) for n + 2 ⩽ k ⩽ 2n. For our purpose, the following properties of p n ( x ), q n ( x ) and r n ( x ) are necessary. Their proofs are straightforward and are omitted. Lemma 2.3 r n ( x ) = r n +1 ( x ) − 3 x + 6 n − 1. Lemma 2.4 r n (x) = r n+1 (x + 1) − 2x + 3n. Lemma 2.5 r n (x) = r n+1 (x + 2) − x + 2. Lemma 2.6 r n (x) = r n+1 (x + 3) − 3n + 5. Lemma 2.7 p n (x) + q n (y) = r n+1 (x + y) + (x − n − 1)(y − 2n). Lemma 2.8 p n (x) + r n (y) = r n+1 (x + y) + (x − 3)(y − 2n). Lemma 2.9 q n (x) + q n (y) = r n+1 (x + y) + (x − n − 1)(y − n − 1). 3 Main result The main result of this paper is formulated below. Theorem 3.1 Let G be an n-dimensional generalized cube. Then θ G (k) ⩾ r n (k) for 2n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3n − 2. Moreover, this inequality is optimal in that θ Q n ( k ) = r n ( k ) for 2n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3n − 2. In order to prove this theorem, we need the following three lemmas. Lemma 3.2 Let G be a graph on N nodes. Then θ G (k + 1) ⩾ θ G (k) − 1 for 0 ⩽ k ⩽ N − 1. Proof Let S be an arbitrary set of ( k + 1) nodes in G . It suffices to show that ∣ N G ( S )∣ ⩾ θ G ( k ) − 1. Let u be a node in S . We have ∣ N G ( S − { u })∣ ⩾ θ G ( k ). Let f ( u ) = | { v ∈ N G ( u ) : v ∉ N G [ S - { u } ] } | , g ( u ) = 1 , u is adjacent to some node in S - { u } ; 0 , otherwise . Then ∣ N G ( S )∣ = ∣ N G ( S − { u })∣ + f ( u ) − g ( u ) ⩾ ∣ N G ( S − { u })∣ − 1 ⩾ θ G ( k ) − 1. □ Lemma 3.3 Let G be an n-dimensional generalized cube. Then θ G (k) ⩾ r n (k) for 2n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3n − 2. Proof We argue by induction on the dimensionality of the generalized cubes. This claim is obviously true for the two three-dimensional generalized cubes shown in Fig. 2.1 . Suppose that this claim is true for all the m -dimensional generalized cubes, where m ⩾ 3 is any given integer. Now, consider an arbitrary ( m + 1)-dimensional generalized cube G = ( G 1 , G 2 ; M ϕ ). Let S be an arbitrary set of k nodes in G , where 2 m + 3 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 m + 1. We need to show ∣ N G ( S )∣ ⩾ r m +1 ( k ). To this end, we let S 1 = S ∩ V ( G 1 ), k 1 = ∣ S 1 ∣, S 2 = S ∩ V ( G 2 ), k 2 = ∣ S 2 ∣. Without loss of generality, we may assume k 1 ⩽ k 2 . Then k 1 ⩽ ⌊ k /2⌋ ⩽ ⌊(3 m + 1)/2⌋ ⩽ 2 m . Let T denote the set of the ϕ -neighbors of all the nodes in S 2 . We proceed by distinguishing among five possibilities. Case 1. k 1 = 0. We further consider four subcases. Subcase 1.1. 2 m + 3 ⩽ k 2 ⩽ 3 m − 2. It follows from the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.3 that | N G ( S ) | = | T | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ k 2 + θ G 2 ( k 2 ) ⩾ k 2 + r m ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k 2 ) - 2 k 2 + 6 m - 1 ⩾ r m + 1 ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 1.2. k 2 = 3 m − 1. It follows from Lemma 3.2 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.4 that | N G ( S ) | = | T | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( 3 m - 1 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 1 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 2 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + r m ( 3 m - 2 ) = r m + 1 ( 3 m - 1 ) + 2 ⩾ r m + 1 ( 3 m - 1 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 1.3. k 2 = 3 m . It follows from Lemma 3.2 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.5 that | N G ( S ) | = | T | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ 3 m + θ G 2 ( 3 m ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 2 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + r m ( 3 m - 2 ) = r m + 1 ( 3 m ) + 2 ⩾ r m + 1 ( 3 m ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 1.4. k 2 = 3 m + 1. It follows from Lemma 3.2 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.6 that | N G ( S ) | = | T | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( 3 m + 1 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m + 1 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 2 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + r m ( 3 m - 2 ) = r m + 1 ( 3 m + 1 ) + 3 ⩾ r m + 1 ( 3 m + 1 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Case 2. k 1 = 1. We further consider three subcases. Subcase 2.1. 2 m + 2 ⩽ k 2 ⩽ 3 m − 2. It follows from the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.4 that | N G ( S ) | ⩾ | T - S 1 | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( k 2 - 1 ) + θ G 2 ( k 2 ) ⩾ ( k 2 - 1 ) + r m ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k 2 + 1 ) - k 2 + 3 m - 1 ⩾ r m + 1 ( k 2 + 1 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 2.2. k 2 = 3 m − 1. It follows from Lemma 3.2 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.5 that | N G ( S ) | = | T - S 1 | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( 3 m - 2 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 1 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 3 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 2 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 3 ) + r m ( 3 m - 2 ) = r m + 1 ( 3 m ) + 1 ⩾ r m + 1 ( 3 m ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 2.3 . k 2 = 3 m . It follows from Lemma 3.2 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.6 that | N G ( S ) | = | T - S 1 | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( 3 m - 1 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 3 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 2 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 3 ) + r m ( 3 m - 2 ) = r m + 1 ( 3 m + 1 ) + 2 ⩾ r m + 1 ( 3 m + 1 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Case 3. k 1 = 2. We further consider two subcases. Subcase 3.1. 2 m + 1 ⩽ k 2 ⩽ 3 m − 2. It follows from the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.5 that | N G ( S ) | = | T - S 1 | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( k 2 - 2 ) + θ G 2 ( k 2 ) ⩾ ( k 2 - 2 ) + r m ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k 2 + 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 3.2. k 2 = 3 m − 1. It follows from Lemma 3.2 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.6 that | N G ( S ) | = | T - S 1 | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ ( 3 m - 3 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 1 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 4 ) + θ G 2 ( 3 m - 2 ) ⩾ ( 3 m - 4 ) + r m ( 3 m - 2 ) = r m + 1 ( 3 m + 1 ) + 1 ⩾ r m + 1 ( 3 m + 1 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Case 4. 3 ⩽ k 1 ⩽ m + 1. Then m + 2 = ( 2 m + 3 ) - ( m + 1 ) ⩽ k - ( m + 1 ) ⩽ k 2 ⩽ k - 3 ⩽ ( 3 m + 1 ) - 3 = 3 m - 2 . We have two possibilities. Subcase 4.1. m + 2 ⩽ k 2 ⩽ 2 m . From Lemmas 2.1, 2.2 and 2.7 , we get | N G ( S ) | ⩾ | N G 1 ( S 1 ) | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ θ G 1 ( k 1 ) + θ G 2 ( k 2 ) ⩾ p m ( k 1 ) + q m ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k 1 + k 2 ) + ( k 1 - m - 1 ) ( k 2 - 2 m ) ⩾ r m + 1 ( k 1 + k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Subcase 4.2. 2 m + 1 ⩽ k 2 ⩽ 3 m − 2. From Lemma 2.1 , the inductive hypothesis and Lemma 2.8 , we get | N G ( S ) | ⩾ | N G 1 ( S 1 ) | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ θ G 1 ( k 1 ) + θ G 2 ( k 2 ) ⩾ p m ( k 1 ) + r m ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k 1 + k 2 ) + ( k 1 - 3 ) ( k 2 - 2 m ) ⩾ r m + 1 ( k 1 + k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . Case 5 . m + 2 ⩽ k 1 ⩽ 2 m . Then m + 2 ⩽ k 1 ⩽ k 2 ⩽ k - ( m + 2 ) ⩽ ( 3 m + 1 ) - ( m + 2 ) = 2 m - 1 . From Lemmas 2.2 and 2.9 , we get | N G ( S ) | ⩾ | N G 1 ( S 1 ) | + | N G 2 ( S 2 ) | ⩾ θ G 1 ( k 1 ) + θ G 2 ( k 2 ) ⩾ q m ( k 1 ) + q m ( k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k 1 + k 2 ) + ( k 1 - m - 1 ) ( k 2 - m - 1 ) ⩾ r m + 1 ( k 1 + k 2 ) = r m + 1 ( k ) . From the previous discussions, we induce that the claim is true for all the ( m + 1)-dimensional generalized cubes. This completes the inductive proof of the lemma. □ Lemma 3.4 θ Q n ( k ) = r n ( k ) for 2n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3n − 2. Proof From Lemma 3.3 , we have θ Q n ( k ) ⩾ r n ( k ) for 2n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 n − 2. On the other hand, we choose a set S of k nodes from Q n by employing the following breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm: ALGORITHM CHOOSE_NODE INPUT: An integer n ⩾ 1; an integer k satisfying 0 ⩽ k ⩽ 2 n . OUTPUT: A set S of k nodes in Q n . BEGIN /* Whenever all of the nodes in Q n need to be scanned, the scanning proceeds from node 0 n to node 1 n in the lexical order; */ FOR each node u in Q n Label u with “unelected”; Let Q be an initially empty queue; Let S be an initially empty set; IF k > 0 THEN BEGIN Add node 0 n to Q ; Label node 0 n with “elected”; END; WHILE ∣ S ∣ < k DO BEGIN Let u be the first node in Q ; Remove u from Q ; Add u to S ; FOR each node v in Q n IF ( v is adjacent to u ) & ( v is “unelected”) THEN BEGIN Add v to Q ; Label v with “elected”; END; END; END. For example, when running on n = 4 and k = 9, algorithm CHOOSE_NODE will return S = {0000, 0001, 0010, 0100, 1000, 0011, 0101, 1001, 0110} (see Fig. 3.1 ). Given any integer n ⩾ 3 and any integer k satisfying 2 n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 n − 2, let S n , k denote the node subset obtained by running algorithm CHOOSE_NODE on n and k . It is easily verified that | N Q n ( S n , k ) | = n + [ ( n - 2 ) + ( n - 3 ) + ⋯ + ( - 1 ) ] + [ ( n - 3 ) + ( n - 4 ) + ⋯ + ( - 1 ) ] + { ( n - 4 ) + ( n - 5 ) + ⋯ + [ n - ( k - 2 n ) - 3 ] } = - 1 2 k 2 + 3 n - 7 2 k - 3 n 2 + 4 n + 2 = r n ( k ) . This implies θ Q n ( k ) ⩽ r n ( k ) . □ We are ready to complete the proof of Theorem 3.1 . Proof of Theorem 3.1 It follows from Lemmas 3.3 and 3.4 . □ 4 Conclusions The minimum k -neighborhood problem is not only of theoretic interest, but the obtained result is useful in the evaluation of fault tolerance and diagnosability of multiprocessor systems. In this paper, we have presented a tight lower bound on the size of a k -neighborhood in any n -dimensional generalized cube, where 2 n + 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 n − 2. When 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 3 n − 2, the result presented in this paper and those given in [9,22] jointly give a tight lower bound on the size of a k -neighborhood in an n -dimensional generalized cube. When 3 n − 1 ⩽ k ⩽ 2 n , the minimum k -neighborhood problem remains open for n -dimensional generalized cubes. CFwQWYsi.title: Generalized honeycomb torus is hamiltonian
CFwQWYsi.abstract: Generalized honeycomb torus is a candidate for interconnection network architectures, which includes honeycomb torus, honeycomb rectangular torus, and honeycomb parallelogramic torus as special cases. Existence of Hamiltonian cycle is a basic requirement for interconnection networks since it helps map a "token ring" parallel algorithm onto the associated network in an efficient way. Cho and Hsu [Inform. Process. Lett. 86 (4) (2003) 185-190] speculated that every generalized honeycomb torus is Hamiltonian. In this paper, we have proved this conjecture.

tVdPnLsE.title: Realizing the ternary n-cube communication pattern on a ring-connected WDM optical network
tVdPnLsE.abstract: The k-ary n-cube, denoted Qnk, turns out to be a popular communication pattern for parallel processing. This paper focuses on the issue of efficiently executing a parallel algorithm with bidirectional/unidirectional ternary n-cube communication pattern on a ring-connected WDM optical network. For either of these two communication patterns, a routing scheme is suggested, and the corresponding wavelength assignment strategy is presented. For the bidirectional communication, the number of wavelengths required by the proposed embedding scheme is shown to attain the minimum. We conjecture that the congestion of the embedding Qn3 in C3n is minimal regardless of the embedding scheme. ? 2013 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

6Q8d1X5g.title: Generation of delayed chaotic neuron with an axisymmetric activation function
6Q8d1X5g.abstract: This paper addresses generation of delayed chaotic neuron with an axisymmetric activation function. The mathematical model of the proposed system with piecewise-linear (PWL) function is described. An electronic circuitry implementation of this system is also considered in detail. Notably, the proposed PWL circuit unit can also be used as an activation function unit in different systems, such as the famous piecewise function unit of Chuapsilas diode.

iIAEx9OZ.title: Optimal wavelength assignment in the implementation of parallel algorithms with ternary n-cube communication pattern on mesh optical network
iIAEx9OZ.abstract: Multi-ary n-cubes are a class of communication patterns that are employed by a number of typical parallel algorithms. This paper addresses the implementation of parallel algorithms with bidirectional and unidirectional ternary n-cube communication patterns on a mesh WDM optical network. For each of these two communication patterns, a routing and wavelength assignment scheme is described, and the number of wavelengths required is shown to attain the minimum, which guarantees the optimality of the proposed scheme.

AyB901uI.title: The pulse treatment of computer viruses: a modeling study
AyB901uI.abstract: Unlike new medical procedures, new antivirus software can be disseminated rapidly through the Internet and takes effect immediately after it is run. As a result, a considerable number of infected computers can be cured almost simultaneously. Consequently, it is of practical importance to understand how pulse treatment affects the spread of computer viruses. For this purpose, an impulsive malware propagation model is proposed. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first computer virus model that takes into account the effect of pulse treatment. The dynamic properties of this model are investigated comprehensively. Specifically, it is found that (a) the virus-free periodic solution is globally asymptotically stable when the basic reproduction ratio (BRR) is less than unity, (b) infections are permanent when the BRR exceeds unity, and (c) a locally asymptotically stable viral periodic solution bifurcates from the virus-free periodic solution when the BRR goes through unity. A close inspection of the influence of different model parameters on the BRR allows us to suggest some feasible measures of eradicating electronic infections.

R4V4ujKd.title: Construction of multidimensional morphological wavelets based on lifting scheme
R4V4ujKd.abstract: The construction of multidimensional morphological wavelets is addressed by combining mathematical morphology with multidimensional wavelets. First, the multidimensional multichannel lifting scheme, a general framework of multidimensional morphological wavelet construction, is presented. Then the multidimensional multi-channel Haar morphological wavelets are constructed with max (min) operator. Finally, two examples are given to reveal the advantages and applicability of morphological wavelets.

jwWywPki.title: Routing and wavelength assignment for 3-ary n-cube in array-based optical network
jwWywPki.abstract: The k-ary n-cube, denoted Q"n^k, is one of the popular communication patterns of parallel algorithms. This paper addresses the routing and wavelength assignment for Q"n^3 communication pattern in array-based WDM optical network. By using congestion estimation and giving a routing and wavelength assignment strategy, we prove that the optimal number of wavelengths is 3^n-1.

RBPjciXf.title: iDistance Based Interactive Visual Surveillance Retrieval Algorithm
RBPjciXf.abstract: This paper proposes an iDistance based interactive retrieval algorithm to accomplish semantic retrieval in visual surveillance system and improve the retrieval performance. The concept of user is interactively learned by training a SVM classifier from the user feedbacks. The search range of the algorithm is reduced by an iDistance based optimization algorithm. The surveillance objects are characterized by the color, texture and coefficient trajectory features. Experimental results on real scenes demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.
RBPjciXf.venue: ICICTA '08 Proceedings of the 2008 International Conference on Intelligent Computation Technology and Automation - Volume 01

A5AvS707.title: SIRS model of computer virus propagation based on two-stage immunization
A5AvS707.abstract: For the deficiency of the existing network virus models with immunization,considering the infectious disease model in biology,a Susceptible-Infected-Recovered-Susceptible(SIRS) computer virus propagation model with stage immunization was formulated.The varying probability of being vaccinated when the threshold was reached and its impact on the spread of the virus in the network were considered.Furthermore,with the help of the theory of dynamic stability analysis,the existence and stability conditions of equilibriums were studied.The numerical simulation results illustrate that improving the rate of vaccination and setting a reasonable threshold can effectively constrain virus prevalence in the network.

6dY4cgTq.title: A four-compartment computer virus propagation model with graded infection rate
6dY4cgTq.abstract: A new resident virus propagation model with graded infection rate is established based on the properties of two important stages undergoing by resident virus, which are the latent phase, in which resident virus cannot infect other hosts because it has not yet been loaded into memory and the active phase, in which resident virus resides in memory and infects any suitable program that is executed on the computer. Two computer compartments with different infection rate are established. Furthermore, the dynamic behaviors of this model are investigated by stability theory and numerical simulations. It is found that the dynamical properties of this model are determined by basic reproductive rate. Specifically, virus-free equilibrium is globally asymptotically stable if basic reproductive rate is less than or equal to one , whereas the local asymptotical stability of the viral equilibrium is guaranteed if basic reproductive rate is bigger than one, followed by a conjecture on its global stability. Then the sensitivity analysis of basic reproductive rate to the system parameters is investigated and a collection of policies is advised to control the spread of computer virus over the Internet.

Z16U9yAr.title: The effect of one valence electron: contrasting (PNP)Ni(CO) with (PNP)Ni(NO) to understand the half-bent NiNO unit.
Z16U9yAr.abstract: Reaction of a (PNP)Ni radical with NO finishes in the time of mixing to form a 1:1 adduct with a NO stretching frequency of 1654 cm (-1). NMR data of this diamagnetic product indicate C 2 v symmetry, which is contradicted by the X-ray structure, which shows it to be nonplanar at Ni, with a geometry intermediate between planar and tetrahedral; the planar geometry is thus the transition state for fluxionality giving time-averaged C 2 v symmetry. The X-ray structure, together with DFT calculations, reveals that the "half-bent" NiNO unit and the intermediate coordination geometry result from a Ni --> NO charge transfer, which has a nonintegral value, resulting in a continuum between NO (+) (hence Ni (0)) and NO (-) (hence Ni (II)). This is related to the nonaxially symmetric character of the Ni --> NO back-donation caused by the (PNP) environment on Ni. Steric effects of ( t )Bu and even chelate constraints are ruled out as the cause of the unusual electronic and structural features.

GuYfQ2hA.title: Novel watermarking scheme based on RBF neural network
GuYfQ2hA.abstract: A novel blind watermarking technique based on radial basis function (RBF) neural network is proposed. The proposed watermarking algorithm scrambles the binary image watermark that may protect copyright and embeds it into the low frequency wavelet coefficients of the host image. The human visual system (HVS) characteristics are taken into consideration during the watermark embedding process so as to keep the watermark invisible. Then an RBF neural network is used to learn the characteristics of the embedded watermark related to the watermarked image. With the aid of the learning and adaptive capabilities of neural networks, the trained neural network can exactly recover the watermark from the watermarked image. Extensive experiments show that the proposed algorithm has a good imperceptibility and high robustness to various common image processing attacks.

Ngy7PGYh.title: Maximum Profit of Viral Marketing: An Optimal Control Approach
Ngy7PGYh.abstract: Viral marketing, known also as word-of-mouth marketing, is to use consumer-to-consumer communications to disseminate information about a product or service. Firms must persuade consumers, through their personal network and with the support of the Internet to become the vehicles which can disseminate the positive information. This paper addresses the modeling and analysis of the viral marketing for a consistent set of items. We develop a node-level positive comments mixed spreading model with positive comments and discount pricing mechanism, and thereby we measure the profit of the marketing. Next, we show that the model admits an optimal control, and we present the optimality system for solving the model. Finally, we give some optimal strategies by solving the corresponding optimality systems.

cDl1EMjD.title: CO oxidation on supported single Pt atoms: experimental and ab initio density functional studies of CO interaction with Pt atom on θ-Al2O3(010) surface.
cDl1EMjD.abstract: Although there are only a few known examples of supported single-atom catalysts, they are unique because they bridge the gap between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. Here, we report the CO oxidation activity of monodisperse single Pt atoms supported on an inert substrate, θ-alumina (Al2O3), in the presence of stoichiometric oxygen. Since CO oxidation on single Pt atoms cannot occur via a conventional Langmuir-Hinshelwood scheme (L-H scheme) which requires at least one Pt-Pt bond, we carried out a first-principles density functional theoretical study of a proposed pathway which is a variation on the conventional L-H scheme and inspired by the organometallic chemistry of platinum. We find that a single supported Pt atom prefers to bond to O2 over CO. CO then bonds with the oxygenated Pt atom and forms a carbonate which dissociates to liberate CO2, leaving an oxygen atom on Pt. Subsequent reaction with another CO molecule regenerates the single-atom catalyst. The energetics of the proposed mechanism suggests that the single Pt atoms will get covered with CO3 unless the temperature is raised to eliminate CO2. We find evidence for CO3 coverage at room temperature supporting the proposed mechanism in an in situ diffuse reflectance infrared study of CO adsorption on the catalyst's supported single atoms. Thus, our results clearly show that supported Pt single atoms are catalytically active and that this catalytic activity can occur without involving the substrate. Characterization by electron microscopy and X-ray absorption studies of the monodisperse Pt/θ-Al2O3 are also presented.

kMlVuWrK.title: Generalized knight's tour on 3D chessboards
kMlVuWrK.abstract: In [G.L. Chia, Siew-Hui Ong, Generalized knight's tours on rectangular chessboards, Discrete Applied Mathematics 150 (2005) 80-98], Chia and Ong proposed the notion of the generalized knight's tour problem (GKTP). In this paper, we address the 3D GKTP, that is, the GKTP on 3D chessboards of size LxMxN, where L@?M@?N. We begin by presenting several sufficient conditions for a 3D chessboard not to admit a closed or open generalized knight's tour (GKT) with given move patterns. Then, we turn our attention to the 3D GKTP with (1, 2, 2) move. First, we show that a chessboard of size LxMxN does not have a closed GKT if either (a) L@?2 or L=4, or (b) L=3 and M@?7. Then, we constructively prove that a chessboard of size 3x4sx4t with s=2and t=2 must contain a closed GKT.

JqFJkcbS.title: Optimal doublecast path in hexagonal honeycomb mesh
JqFJkcbS.abstract: The performance of a multicomputer is greatly dependent on the multicast strategy, i.e., how to deliver the same message from a source node to a number of destination nodes. Building an optimal multicast path is suited for multicast wormhole routing. A doublecast path is a multicast path with exactly two destination nodes. Hexagonal honeycomb mesh is a promising candidate for interconnection networks. This paper addresses the building of an optimal doublecast path on hexagonal honeycomb mesh. A theorem concerned with the length of an optimal doublecast path is established, and a time-optimal algorithm for building an optimal doublecast path is proposed. (c) 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

yhctIbL2.title: Distributed interaction between computer virus and patch: A modeling study.
yhctIbL2.abstract: The decentralized patch distribution mechanism holds significant promise as an alternative to its centralized counterpart. For the purpose of accurately evaluating the performance of the decentralized patch distribution mechanism and based on the exact SIPS model that accurately captures the average dynamics of the interaction between viruses and patches, a new virus-patch interacting model, which is known as the generic SIPS model, is proposed. This model subsumes the linear SIPS model. The dynamics of the generic SIPS model is studied comprehensively. In particular, a set of criteria for the final extinction or/and long-term survival of viruses or/and patches are presented. Some conditions for the linear SIPS model to accurately capture the average dynamics of the virus-patch interaction are empirically found. As a consequence, the linear SIPS model can be adopted as a standard model for assessing the performance of the distributed patch distribution mechanism, provided the proper conditions are satisfied.

cIUTMT6Y.title: A comparison-based diagnosis algorithm tailored for crossed cube multiprocessor systems
cIUTMT6Y.abstract: Comparison-based diagnosis is an effective approach to system-level fault diagnosis. Under the Maeng–Malek comparison model (MM* model), Sengupta and Dahbura proposed an O( N 5 ) diagnosis algorithm for general diagnosable systems with N nodes. Thanks to lower diameter and better graph embedding capability as compared with a hypercube of the same size, the crossed cube has been a promising candidate for interconnection networks. In this paper, we propose a fault diagnosis algorithm tailored for crossed cube connected multicomputer systems under the MM* model. By introducing appropriate data structures, this algorithm runs in O ( N log 2 2 N ) time, which is linear in the size of the input. As a result, this algorithm is significantly superior to the Sengupta–Dahbura's algorithm when applied to crossed cube systems.

uPBs42eH.title: Fault-tolerant Hamiltonicity in a class of faulty meshes
uPBs42eH.abstract: This paper addresses the Hamiltonian properties of rectangular meshes with faulty nodes. We present a necessary and sufficient condition for an m × n mesh ( m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 are even) with two faulty nodes to have a fault-free Hamiltonian cycle, which generalizes a result owing to Kim and Yoon [J.S. Kim, S.H. Yoon, Embedding of rings in 2-D meshes and tori with faulty nodes, Journal of Systems Architecture 43 (9) (1997) 643–654]. We also describe an efficient scheme for constructing such a fault-free Hamiltonian cycle, if there is. Keywords Mesh Hamiltonian cycle Fault tolerance 1 Introduction A two-dimensional (2D) rectangular mesh can be laid out on a VLSI chip in an area that increases linearly with the number of processors (nodes). Because of the short, local connections between nodes, the area consumed by the wires is negligible, and the signal propagation delay between adjacent nodes is quite small. Due to these advantages, 2D meshes have received considerable attention from parallel processing community, and a number of mesh-connected parallel computers are commercially available [9] . In the design of parallel algorithms, linear arrays and rings are two typical communication schemes between processes. In order to efficiently implement a linear-array-based or ring-based parallel algorithm on a mesh-connected parallel computer, one needs to find a long path/cycle within the mesh network. Chen et al. [2] presented a fast sequential algorithm as well as its parallelized version for constructing Hamiltonian paths between two nodes in a mesh. Collins and Krompart [4] and Stoyan and Strehl [11] studied the number of Hamiltonian paths and Hamiltonian cycles in a mesh, respectively. The growing size of mesh-connected computer systems increases the probability of the event that there exist failing nodes in such systems. To maintain system’s high availability, it is crucial to locate the faulty nodes therein by means of system-level fault diagnosis [1] . Once the failing nodes are identified, the next work is to identify a long fault-free path/cycle. Itai et al. [6] proved that it is NP-complete to determine whether a 2D-mesh with arbitrary fault nodes possesses a Hamiltonian cycle; so no polynomial-time algorithm exists for this problem unless P = NP. Hedetniemi et al. [5] proposed a ring embedding method in a mesh with a single faulty node. Kim and Yoon [7] found a necessary and sufficient condition for a Hamiltonian m × n mesh ( m and n are multiples of four) in the presence of two faulty nodes; they also devised an algorithm for constructing such a Hamiltonian cycle, if there is, by partitioning the original mesh into 4 × 4 submeshes, building an appropriate fault-free Hamiltonian path for each submesh, and merging these short paths to yield a fault-free Hamiltonian cycle of the original mesh. For some related work the reader is referred to [3,8,10] . This paper addresses the Hamiltonian properties of an m × n mesh ( m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 are even) in the presence of two failing nodes. We give a necessary and sufficient condition for such a faulty mesh to have a Hamiltonian cycle; our condition generalizes a result owing to Kim and Yoon [7] . Furthermore, we describe a systematic method for constructing such a Hamiltonian cycle, if there is; our method is different from the one used by Kim and Yoon in that the original mesh is partitioned into atmost five submeshes instead of a large number of 4 × 4 submeshes. The materials of this work are organized as follows. Section 2 provides the preliminary knowledge. The Hamiltonian properties of some typical (complete or incomplete) meshes are explored in Section 3 . Based on this, the main theorem of this work is established in Section 4 . We make some remarks in Section 5 to close our work. 2 Preliminaries An m × n (rectangular) mesh is a graph of m × n nodes arranged in m rows and n columns, where the node lying in the i th row and j th column is identified with an ordered pair ( i , j ), and two nodes ( i , j ), ( k , l ) are adjacent if and only if either (a) i = k , ∣ j − l ∣ = 1, or (b) j = l , ∣ i − k ∣ = 1. Fig. 2.1 shows a 6 × 8 mesh. An m × n mesh is a bipartite graph with the bipartition ( U 0 , U 1 ), where U 0 = { ( i , j ) : 1 ⩽ i ⩽ m , 1 ⩽ j ⩽ n , i + j is even } , U 1 = { ( i , j ) : 1 ⩽ i ⩽ m , 1 ⩽ j ⩽ n , i + j is odd } . A mesh possesses multiple submeshes; each of such submeshes can be uniquely determined by its top-left corner node and bottom-right corner node. In what follows we use the symbol M (( i , j ), ( k , l )) to denote the submesh with ( i , j ) and ( k , l ) as the top-left corner and bottom-right corner nodes, respectively. Fig. 2.2 gives two illustrative submeshes in a 6 × 8 mesh. Especially, an m × n mesh is denoted by M ((1, 1), ( m , n )). An m × n torus is obtained from an m × n mesh by adding all the edges 〈(1, i ), ( m , i )〉 (1 ⩽ i ⩽ n ) and 〈( j , 1), ( j , n )〉 (1 ⩽ j ⩽ m ), which is denoted by T ((1, 1), ( m , n )). Fig. 2.3 shows a 6 × 8 torus. 3 Hamiltonian properties of some complete and incomplete meshes In this section, the Hamiltonian properties of some typical complete and incomplete meshes are explored, which will be useful for the establishment of the main result of this paper. Lemma 3.1 Let m ⩾ 1 be an integer, n ⩾ 2 an even number. Then the mesh M((1, 1), (m, n)) has a Hamiltonian path from node (1, 1) to node (1, n). Proof We can build a Hamiltonian path of M ((1, 1), ( m , n )) as follows: ( 1 , 1 ) → along the first column ( m , 1 ) → ( m , 2 ) → along the second column ( 1 , 2 ) → ( 1 , 3 ) → ⋯ → ( 1 , n - 1 ) → along the ( n - 1 ) th column ( m , n - 1 ) → ( m , n ) → along the n th column ( 1 , n ) . Fig. 3.1 shows such a Hamiltonian path of M ((1, 1), (5, 8)). □ In what follows we refer to such a Hamiltonian path of M ((1, 1), ( m , n )) as a ladder - shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, 1) to node (1, n ). Lemma 3.2 Let m ⩾ 2 be an integer, n ⩾ 2 an even number. Then the mesh M((1, 1), (m, n)) has a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof We can build a Hamiltonian cycle as follows. First, we construct a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path of the submesh M ((2, 1), ( m , n )) from node (2, 1) to node (2, n ). Second, we build a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path of the submesh M ((1, 1), (1, n )) from node (1, 1) to node (1, n ). Then we have a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), ( m , n )) from these two paths by adding two edges 〈(1, 1), (2, 1)〉 and 〈(1, n ), (2, n )〉. Fig. 3.2 shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (5, 8)). □ In what follows we refer to such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), ( m , n )) as a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the first row as reference . Lemma 3.3 Let m ⩾ 3 be an odd number, n ⩾ 4 an even number. Let G = M((1, 1), (m, n)) − { (1, 1), (m, n) } . Then G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof There are two possibilities. Case 1 : n = 4. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , 2)) − (1, 1), G 2 = M ((1, 3), ( m , 4)) − ( m , 4). Clearly, G 1 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, 2) to node ( m , 2), G 2 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, 3) to node ( m , 3). We then obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two paths by adding two edges 〈(1, 2), (1, 3)〉 and 〈( m , 2), ( m , 3)〉. Fig. 3.3 (a) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (5, 4)) − {(1, 1), (5, 4)}. Case 2 : n ⩾ 6. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , 2)) − (1, 1), G 2 = M ((1, n − 1), ( m , n )) − ( m , n ), G 3 = M ((1, 3), ( m − 1, n − 2)), G 4 = M (( m , 3), ( m , n − 2)). Clearly, G 1 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, 2) to node ( m , 2), G 2 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, n − 1) to node ( m , n − 1). From Lemma 3.1 , G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, 3) to node (1, n − 2), G 4 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node ( m , 3) to node ( m , n − 2). We can obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these four paths by adding four edges 〈(1, 2), (1, 3)〉, 〈(1, n − 2), (1, n − 1)〉, 〈( m , 2), ( m , 3)〉, 〈( m , n − 2), ( m , n − 1)〉. Fig. 3.3 (b) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (7, 8)) − {(1, 1), (7,8)}. □ Lemma 3.4 Let m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 be a pair of even numbers. Let P(p 1 , p 2 ), and Q(q 1 , q 2 ) be a pair of nodes of M((1, 1), (m, n)) such that 2 ⩽ p 1 ⩽ q 1 ⩽ m − 1, 2 ⩽ p 2 ⩽ q 2 ⩽ n − 1, q 2 − p 2 is odd. Let G = M((1, 1), (m, n)) − M(P, Q). Then G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , p 2 − 1)), G 2 = M ((1, q 2 + 1), ( m , n )), G 3 = M ((1, p 2 ), ( p 1 − 1, q 2 )), G 4 = M (( q 1 + 1, p 2 ),( m , q 2 )). From Lemma 3.1 , G 1 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, p 2 − 1) to node ( m , p 2 − 1), G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, q 2 + 1) to node ( m , q 2 + 1), G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, p 2 ) to node (1, q 2 ), G 4 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node ( m , p 2 ) to node ( m , q 2 ). We then obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these four paths by adding four edges 〈(1, p 2 − 1), (1, p 2 )〉, 〈(1, q 2 ), (1, q 2 + 1)〉, 〈( m , p 2 − 1), ( m , p 2 )〉, 〈( m , q 2 ), ( m , q 2 + 1)〉. Fig. 3.4 shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (10, 10)) − {(3, 2), (7, 7)}. □ Lemma 3.5 Let m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 2 be a pair of even numbers. Let P = (1, 1) and Q = (q, n) be a pair of nodes of M((1, 1), (m, n)), where q is odd. Let G = M((1, 1), (m, n)) − { P, Q } . Then G admits a Hamiltonian path from node (1, n) to node (m, n). Proof The affirmation is obvious for the case where n = 2. Fig. 3.5 (a) gives such a Hamiltonian path of M ((1, 1), (8, 2)) − {(1, 1), (5, 2)}. We now assume n ⩾ 4. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( q − 1, 2)) − P , G 2 = M (( q , n − 1), ( m , n )) − Q , G 3 = M ((1, 3), ( q − 1, n )), G 4 = M (( q , 1),( m , n − 2)). Clearly, G 1 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, 2) to node ( q − 1, 1), G 2 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node ( q , n − 1) to node ( m , n ). From Lemma 3.1 , G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, 3) to node (1, n ), G 4 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node ( q , 1) to node ( q , n − 2). From these four paths and by adding three edges 〈(1, 2), (1, 3)〉, 〈( q − 1, 1), ( q , 1)〉, 〈( q , n − 2), ( q , n − 1)〉, we get a Hamiltonian path of G from node (1, n ) to node ( m , n ). Fig. 3.5 (b) shows such a Hamiltonian path of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(1, 1), (5, 8)}. □ Lemma 3.6 Let n ⩾ 4 be an even number. Let P = (2, p) and Q = (3, q) be a pair of nodes of M((1, 1), (4, n)), where 2 ⩽ p < q ⩽ n − 1, q − p is even. Let G = M((1, 1), (4, n)) − { P, Q } . Then G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof We may assume p is odd; otherwise we can rotate the mesh by 180° and view Q as P instead. Let G 1 = M ((1, p ), (2, n )) − P , G 2 = M ((3, p ), (4, n )) − Q , G 3 = ((1, 1), (4, p − 1)). Clearly, G 1 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, p ) to node (2, n ), G 2 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (4, p ) to node (3, n ), G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, p − 1) to node (4, p − 1). We obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these three paths by adding three edges 〈(1, p − 1), (1, p )〉, 〈(4, p − 1), (4, p )〉, 〈(2, n ), (3, n )〉. Fig. 3.6 gives such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (4, 10)) − {(2, 3), (3, 7)}. □ Lemma 3.7 Let n ⩾ 4 be an even integer. Let P = (3, p) and Q = (4, q) be a pair of nodes of M((1, 1), (4, n)), where 2 ⩽ p < q ⩽ n − 2, q − p is even. Let G = M((1, 1), (4, n)) − { P, Q } . Then G has a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof Let G 1 = M ((3, p ), (4, q + 1)) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, p ), (2, q + 1)), G 3 = ((1, 1), (4, p − 1)), G 4 = ((1, q + 2), (4, n )). Clearly, G 1 possesses a unique Hamiltonian path from node (4, p ) to node (4, q + 1), G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, p ) to node (1, q + 1), G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, p − 1) to node (4, p − 1), G 4 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, q + 2) to node (4, q + 2). We have a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these four paths by adding four edges 〈(1, p − 1), (1, p )〉, 〈(4, p − 1), (4, p )〉, 〈(1, q + 1), (1, q + 2)〉, 〈(4, q + 1), (4, q + 2)〉. Fig. 3.7 shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (4, 10)) − {(3, 3), (4, 7)}. □ Lemma 3.8 Let m ⩾ 3 be an integer, n ⩾ 4 be an even number. Let G = M((1, 1), (m, n)) − { (1, 1), (1, n) } . Then G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), (2, n )) − {(1, 1), (1, n )}, G 2 = M ((3, 1), ( m , n )). Clearly, G 1 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (2, 1) to node (2, n ), G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (3, 1) to node (3, n ). From these two paths and by adding two edges 〈(2, 1), (3, 1)〉 and 〈(2, n ), (3, n )〉, we obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G . Fig. 3.8 gives such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (5, 6)) − {(1, 1), (1, 6)}. □ Lemma 3.9 Let n ⩾ 4 be an even number. Let P = (2, p) and Q = (2, q) be a pair of nodes of M((1, 1), (4, n)), where 2 ⩽ p < q ⩽ n − 1, q − p is odd. Let G = M((1, 1), (4, n)) − { P, Q } . Then G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Proof Let G 1 = M ((1, p ), (2, q )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((3, p ), (4, q )), G 3 = M ((1, 1), (4, p − 1)), G 4 = M ((1, q + 1), (4, n )). Clearly, G 1 possesses a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, p ) to node (1, q ), G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (4, p ) to node (4, q ), G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, p − 1) to node (4, p − 1), G 4 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, q + 1) to node (4, q + 1). A Hamiltonian cycle of G is formed from these four paths by adding four edges 〈(1, p − 1), (1, p )〉, 〈(4, p − 1), (4, p )〉, 〈(1, q ), (1, q + 1)〉, 〈(4, q ), (4, q + 1)〉. Fig. 3.9 gives such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (4, 10)) − {(2, 2), (2, 7)}. □ 4 Main result The main result of this paper is formulated below. Theorem 4.1 Let m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 be a pair of even numbers. Let P and Q be a pair of nodes of the mesh M((1, 1), (m, n)). Let U 0 = { (i, j) : 1 ⩽ i ⩽ m, 1 ⩽ j ⩽ n, i + j is even } , U 1 = { (i, j) : 1 ⩽ i ⩽ m, 1 ⩽ j ⩽ n, i + j is odd } . Then the faulty mesh M((1, 1), (m, n)) − { P, Q } does not admit a Hamiltonian cycle if and only if either of the following two conditions is satisfied: ( C 1) Either both P and Q belong to U 0 , or both belong to U 1 . ( C 2) One of P and Q is next to some corner node of the original mesh, but the other is not this corner node. Proof If either of the two conditions is satisfied, the nonexistence of a Hamiltonian cycle of the faulty mesh is obvious. We now assume neither of these two conditions holds. It suffices to build a Hamiltonian cycle of the faulty mesh. To this end, let P = ( p 1 , p 2 ) and Q = ( q 1 , q 2 ). Then p 1 + p 2 is different from q 1 + q 2 in parity. In view of the symmetry of 2D meshes, we may assume p 1 ⩽ q 1 , p 2 ⩽ q 2 , q 1 − p 1 is even, q 2 − p 2 is odd. Let G = M ((1, 1), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }. We consider the following three possible positional relationships of P and Q . Case 1 : q 1 ⩾ p 1 + 2, q 2 ⩾ p 2 + 3. Case 2 : q 1 ⩾ p 1 + 2, q 2 = p 2 + 1. Case 3 : q 1 = p 1 . Next, these three possibilities are treated, respectively. Case 1 : q 1 ⩾ p 1 + 2, q 2 ⩾ p 2 + 3. Then P cannot lie on the bottom or right border of the original mesh, Q cannot lie on the top or left border of the original mesh. Subcase 1.1 . Neither P nor Q lies on the border of the mesh. That is, p 1 ⩾ 2, p 2 ⩾ 2, q 1 ⩽ m − 1, q 2 ⩽ n − 1. Let G 1 = M ( P , Q ) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( m , n )) − M ( P , Q ). Let e 1 = 〈( p 1 , q 2 − 1), ( p 1 , q 2 )〉, e 2 = 〈( p 1 − 1, q 2 − 1), ( p 1 − 1, q 2 )〉. From Lemma 3.3 , G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.4 , G 2 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 2 . Thus, a Hamiltonian cycle of G can be obtained from these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 , e 2 , and adding two edges 〈( p 1 − 1, q 2 − 1), ( p 1 , q 2 − 1)〉, 〈( p 1 − 1, q 2 ), ( p 1 , q 2 )〉. Fig. 4.1 (a) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (10, 10)) − {(3, 3), (7, 8)}. Subcase 1.2 . P is the top-left corner node of the original mesh. (The argument for the case where Q lies on the bottom-right corner of the original mesh is similar.) Subcase 1.2.1 . Q is on the right border of the original mesh. Clearly, q 1 ⩽ m − 2. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( q 1 , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M (( q 1 + 1, 1), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈( q 1 , 1), ( q 1 , 2)〉, e 2 = 〈( q 1 + 1, 1), ( q 1 + 1, 2)〉. From Lemma 3.3 , G 1 contains a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( q 1 + 1)th row as reference, which traverses e 2 . We then have a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈( q 1 , 1), ( q 1 + 1, 1)〉, 〈( q 1 , 2), ( q 1 + 1, 2)〉. Fig. 4.1 (b) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(1, 1), (5, 8)}. Subcase 1.2.2 . Q is not on the right border of the original mesh. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , q 2 )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, q 2 + 1), ( m , n )). According to Lemma 3.5 , G 1 has a Hamiltonian path from node (1, q 2 ) to node ( m , q 2 ). From Lemma 3.1 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, q 2 + 1) to node ( m , q 2 + 1). From these two paths and by adding two edges 〈(1, q 2 ), (1, q 2 + 1)〉 and 〈( m , q 2 ), ( m , q 2 + 1)〉, we get a Hamiltonian cycle of G . Fig. 4.1 (c) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(1, 1), (5, 6)}. Subcase 1.3 . P is on the top border of the original mesh but is not the top-left corner node. (The argument for the case where Q is on the bottom border of the mesh but is not the bottom-right corner node is similar.) Clearly, p 2 ⩾ 3. Let G 1 = M ((1, p 2 ), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( m , p 2 − 1)). Let e 1 = 〈(2, p 2 ), (3, p 2 )〉, e 2 = 〈(2, p 2 − 1), (3, p 2 − 1)〉. Similarly to Subcase 1.2, we can build a Hamiltonian cycle of G 1 , which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 2 − 1)th column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . Thus, we can construct a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(2, p 2 − 1), (2, p 2 )〉 and 〈(3, p 2 − 1), (3, p 2 )〉. Fig. 4.1 (d) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(1, 4), (5, 7)}. Subcase 1.4 . P is on the left border of the original mesh but is not the top-left corner node. (The argument for the case where Q lies on the right border of the mesh but is not the bottom-right corner node is similar.) Clearly, p 1 ⩾ 3. If Q is on the bottom border of the original mesh, the argument will be analogous to Case 1.3. We now assume Q is not on the bottom border of the original mesh. Then there are two possibilities. Subcase 1.4.1 . q 1 is odd. Let G 1 = M (( p 1 , 1), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( p 1 − 1, n )). Let e 1 = 〈( p 1 , 2), ( p 1 , 3)〉, e 2 = 〈( p 1 − 1, 2), ( p 1 − 1, 3)〉. Similarly to Subcase 1.2, we can build a Hamiltonian cycle of G 1 , which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 1 − 1)th row as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . We obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from the two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈( p 1 − 1, 2), ( p 1 , 2)〉, 〈( p 1 − 1, 3), ( p 1 , 3)〉. Fig. 4.1 (e) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(3, 1), (5, 6)}. Subcase 1.4.2 . q 1 is even. Then q 1 ⩽ m − 2. We proceed by further considering two possible cases. Subcase 1.4.2.1 . Q is on the right border of the original mesh. Let G 1 = M (( p 1 , 1), ( q 1 , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( p 1 − 1, n )), G 3 = M (( q 1 + 1, 1), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈( p 1 , 2), ( p 1 , 3)〉, e 2 = 〈( q 1 , 1), ( q 1 , 2)〉, e 3 = 〈( p 1 − 1, 2), ( p 1 − 1, 3)〉, e 4 = 〈( q 1 + 1, 1), ( q 1 + 1, 2)〉. From Lemma 3.3 , G 1 admits a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edges e 1 and e 2 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 1 − 1)th row as reference, which traverses edge e 3 ; G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( q 1 + 1)th row as reference, which traverses edge e 4 . We obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these three cycles by removing four edges e i (1 ⩽ i ⩽ 4) and adding four edges 〈( p 1 − 1, 2), ( p 1 , 2)〉, 〈( p 1 − 1, 3), ( p 1 , 3)〉, 〈( q 1 , 1), ( q 1 + 1, 1)〉, 〈( q 1 , 2), ( q 1 + 1, 2)〉. Fig. 4.1 (f) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(4, 1), (6, 8)}. Subcase 1.4.2.2 . Q is not on the right border of the original mesh. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , q 2 )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, q 2 + 1), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈(1, q 2 ), (2, q 2 )〉, e 2 = 〈(1, q 2 + 1), (2, q 2 + 1)〉. Similarly to Subcase 1.4.2.1, we can build a Hamiltonian cycle of G 1 , which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( q 2 + 1)th column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . We obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(1, q 2 ), (1, q 2 + 1)〉 and 〈(2, q 2 ), (2, q 2 + 1)〉. Fig. 4.1 (g) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(4, 1), (6, 6)}. Case 2 : q 1 ⩾ p 1 + 2, q 2 = p 2 + 1. Without loss of generality, we assume p 1 is odd; otherwise we can rotate the mesh by 180° and view Q as P . Next, we examine three possibilities. Subcase 2.1 . p 2 = 1. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , 2)), G 2 = M ((1, 3), ( m , n )). Clearly, G 1 has a unique Hamiltonian path from node (1, 2) to node ( m , 2). From Lemma 3.1 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from node (1, 3) to node ( m , 3). We obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two paths by adding two edges 〈(1, 2), (1, 3)〉, 〈( m , 2), ( m , 3)〉. Fig. 4.2 (a) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(3, 1), (5, 2)}. Subcase 2.2 . p 2 = 2. Then p 1 ≠ 1. When n = 4, it follows from Lemma 3.6 that G has a Hamiltonian cycle. We now assume n ⩾ 6. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , 4)) − { P , Q }, G 2 = ((1, 5), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈(1, 4), (2, 4)〉, e 2 = 〈(1, 5), (2, 5)〉. From Lemma 3.6 , G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . According to Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the fifth column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . We get a Hamiltonian cycle of G from the two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(1, 4), (1, 5)〉, 〈(2, 4), (2, 5)〉. Fig. 4.2 (b) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(3, 2), (5, 3)}. Subcase 2.3. p 2 ⩾ 3. If n = 4, it follows from Lemma 3.7 that G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Next, we assume n ⩾ 6. Subcase 2.3.1 . q 2 = n . Then p 2 = n − 1. Let G 1 = M ((1, n − 3), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( m , n − 4)). Let e 1 = 〈(1, n − 3), (2, n − 3)〉, e 2 = 〈(1, n − 4), (2, n − 4)〉. According to Lemma 3.7 , G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( n − 4)th column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . We get a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(1, n − 4), (1, n − 3)〉, 〈(2, n − 4), (2, n − 3)〉. Fig. 4.2 (c) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1),(8, 8)) − {(3, 7),(5, 8)}. Subcase 2.3.2 . q 2 ⩽ n − 1. Let G 1 = M ((1, p 2 ), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( m , p 2 − 1)). Let e 1 = 〈( p 1 + 1, p 2 ), ( p 1 + 2, p 2 )〉, e 2 = 〈( p 1 + 1, p 2 − 1), ( p 1 + 2, p 2 − 1)〉. Similarly to Subcase 2.1, G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 2 − 1)th column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . We can form a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈( p 1 + 1, p 2 − 1), ( p 1 + 1, p 2 )〉, 〈( p 1 + 2, p 2 − 1), ( p 1 + 2, p 2 )〉. Fig. 4.2 (d) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(3, 3), (5, 4)}. Case 3 : q 1 = p 1 . Next we consider the value of p 1 . Subcase 3.1 . p 1 = 1. (The case where p 1 = m can be discussed similarly.) When q 1 = 1, q 2 = n , it follows from Lemma 3.8 that G has a Hamiltonian cycle. So there remain three subcases. Subcase 3.1.1 . p 2 = 1, q 2 ⩽ n − 2. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), ( m , q 2 )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, q 2 + 1), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈(2, q 2 ), (3, q 2 )〉, e 2 = 〈(2, q 2 + 1), (3, q 2 + 1)〉. From Lemma 3.8 , G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( q 2 + 1)th column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . From these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(2, q 2 ), (2, q 2 + 1)〉 and 〈(3, q 2 ), (3, q 2 + 1)〉, we obtain a Hamiltonian cycle of G . Fig. 4.3 (a) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(1, 1), (1, 4)}. Subcase 3.1.2 . p 2 ⩾ 3, q 2 = n . The argument is analogous to Subcase 3.1.1. Subcase 3.1.3. p 2 ⩾ 3, q 2 ⩽ n − 2. Let G 1 = M ((1, p 2 ), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( m , p 2 − 1)). Let e 1 = 〈(2, p 2 ), (3, p 2 )〉, e 2 = 〈(2, p 2 − 1), (3, p 2 − 1)〉. Similarly to Subcase 3.1.1, G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 1 − 1)th column as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . From these two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(2, p 2 − 1), (2, p 2 )〉 and 〈(3, p 2 − 1), (3, p 2 )〉, we form a Hamiltonian cycle of G . Fig. 4.3 (b) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(1, 3), (1, 6)}. Subcase 3.2 . p 1 = 2. (The argument for the case where p 1 = m − 1 is similar.) When m = 4, it follows from Lemma 3.9 that G admits a Hamiltonian cycle. Now assume m ⩾ 6. Let G 1 = M ((1, 1), (4, n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((5, 1), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈(4, 1), (4, 2)〉, e 2 = 〈(5, 1), (5, 2)〉. According to Lemma 3.9 , G 1 admits a Hamiltonian cycle, which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the fifth row as reference, which traverses e 2 . From the two cycles by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding two edges 〈(4, 1), (5, 1)〉 and 〈(4, 2), (5, 2)〉, we get a Hamiltonian cycle of G . Fig. 4.3 (c) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(2, 3), (2, 6)}. Subcase 3.3. 3 ⩽ p 1 ⩽ m − 2. Subcase 3.3.1 . p 2 ≠ 2, q 2 ≠ n − 1. Let G 1 = M (( p 1 , 1), ( m , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( p 1 − 1, n )). Similarly to Subcase 3.1, G 1 has a Hamiltonian cycle. From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 1 − 1)th row as reference. We can get a Hamiltonian cycle of G from the two cycles by removing two edges and adding two new edges. Fig. 4.3 (d) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(3, 3), (3, 6)}. Subcase 3.3.2 . p 2 = 2. Then q 2 ≠ n . We may assume p 1 ⩾ 4 (otherwise we can rotate the mesh by 180°). Let G 1 = M (( p 1 − 1, 1), ( p 1 , n )) − { P , Q }, G 2 = M ((1, 1), ( p 1 − 2, n )), G 3 = M (( p 1 + 1, 1), ( m , n )). Let e 1 = 〈( p 1 − 1, 1), ( p 1 − 1, 2)〉, e 2 = 〈( p 1 − 2, 1), ( p 1 − 2, 2)〉. Clearly, G 1 has a Hamiltonian path from ( p 1 , 1) to ( p 1 , n ), which traverses edge e 1 . From Lemma 3.2 , G 2 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian cycle with the ( p 1 − 2)th row as reference, which traverses edge e 2 . From Lemma 3.1 , G 3 has a ladder-shape Hamiltonian path from ( p 1 + 1, 1) to ( p 1 + 1, n ). We can form a Hamiltonian cycle of G from these two paths and this cycle by removing two edges e 1 and e 2 and adding four edges 〈( p 1 − 2, 1), ( p 1 − 1, 1)〉, 〈( p 1 − 2, 2), ( p 1 − 1, 2)〉, 〈( p 1 , 1), ( p 1 + 1, 1)〉, 〈( p 1 , n ), ( p 1 + 1, n )〉. Fig. 4.3 (e) shows such a Hamiltonian cycle of M ((1, 1), (8, 8)) − {(4, 2), (4, 5)}. Subcase 3.3.3 . q 2 = n − 1. The argument is similar to Subcase 3.3.2. The proof has been completed. □ Remark The proof of Theorem 4.1 provides an efficient scheme for constructing a fault-free Hamiltonian cycle in a faulty m × n mesh ( m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 are even), if there is. As a byproduct of Theorem 4.1 , we have Theorem 4.2 Let m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 be a pair of even numbers. Let P and Q be a pair of faulty nodes within the torus T((1, 1), (m, n)). Then the faulty torus T((1, 1), (m, n)) − { P, Q } admits a fault-free Hamiltonian cycle if and only if exactly one node in {P, Q } falls into U 0 . 5 Concluding remarks This paper deals with the Hamiltonian properties of faulty meshes. We give a necessary and sufficient condition for a Hamiltonian m × n mesh ( m ⩾ 4 and n ⩾ 4 are even) at the presence of two faulty nodes. Our conclusion generalizes a result owing to Kim and Yoon [7] . The Hamiltonian properties of faulty meshes need further investigation. It is worthwhile to determine Hamiltonian meshes in the presence of more than two faulty nodes. The work of this paper should be extended to the situation of higher-dimensional meshes. eZddKqyj.title: A fast pessimistic one-step diagnosis algorithm for hypercube multicomputer systems
eZddKqyj.abstract: This paper describes a system-level diagnosis algorithm for hypercube multicomputer systems. The algorithm is based on the PMC model and can isolate all faulty processors to within a set that contains at most one fault-free processor. If we denote by N the total number of processors in a hypercube system to be diagnosed, then, based on the judiciously designed data structures, the algorithm can run in O(N log2 N) time: whereas the best-known diagnosis algorithm, the YML algorithm, runs in O(N2.5) time. Consequently, the new algorithm is remarkably superior to the YML algorithm in terms of the time cost.

pBssyJMV.title: On the system of rational difference equations xn = A + frac(1, yn - p), yn = A + frac(yn - 1, xn - r yn - s)

Ric7bdTG.title: Electronic structure of the water-oxidation catalyst [(bpy)2(OHx)RuORu(OHy)(bpy)2]z+: weak coupling between the metal centers is preferred over strong coupling.
Ric7bdTG.abstract: High-level DFT calculations indicate that the singlet ground state of the water-oxidizing blue Ru dimer [(bpy)2(OH2)RuIIIORuIII(OH2)(bpy)2]4+ is not due to a strong coupling of the excess electrons from each of the low-spin d5 RuIII centers across the Ru-O-Ru moiety, as has been assumed to date. Instead, broken symmetry orbital calculations suggest that a weak antiferromagnetically (AF) coupled singlet state is energetically more favorable by 10-35 kcal/mol. Experimentally observed redox potentials can only be reproduced if antiferromagnetic coupling is invoked.

RZKt4niz.title: The impact of nonlinear infection rate on the spread of computer virus
RZKt4niz.abstract: The dominating majority of previous computer virus epidemic models assume a bilinear infection rate. This assumption, however, ignores the fact that, due to reasons such as overcrowded infected nodes and active protection measures taken at a high level of viral prevalence, the infection rate typically rises in a nonlinear fashion. This paper is devoted to understanding the impact of nonlinear infection rate on the propagation of computer infections. For that purpose, a new computer virus epidemic model is proposed by introducing a generic nonlinear infection rate into a traditional SLBS model. Theoretical analysis shows that, under moderate conditions, the proposed model admits a (viral) globally asymptotically stable equilibrium, fully demonstrating the robustness of stability of the equilibrium to the details of infections. The new model is justified through simulation experiments. We also determine the influence of some model parameters on the viral equilibrium. Our results extend some previously known results.

t2nC6wx5.title: Novel dynamical models on virulence of computer infection
t2nC6wx5.abstract: We apply the idea of evolutionary dynamics into the study of computer viruses. The ultimate objective of our work, which is based on mathematical modeling and is verified by computer simulation, is to explore behavior characteristics of computer viruses during their propagation. We find that, without considering super-infection, the process of virus evolution tends to maximize the basic reproductive ratio. After taking super-infection into account, we analyzed the special case and the general case respectively and formulated the equilibrium solutions of the virulence model under certain assumptions. The two virulence models indicate some inherent features presented by computer viruses, instead of infected computers in the network, which is original to our knowledge. Copyright © 2012 Binary Information Press.

quUaJws2.title: Defending against the Advanced Persistent Threat: An Optimal Control Approach.
quUaJws2.abstract: The new cyberattack pattern of advanced persistent threat (APT) has posed a serious threat to modern society. This paper addresses the APT defense problem, that is, the problem of how to effectively defend against an APT campaign. Based on a novel APT attack-defense model, the effectiveness of an APT defense strategy is quantified. Thereby, the APT defense problem is modeled as an optimal control problem, in which an optimal control stands for a most effective APT defense strategy. The existence of an optimal control is proved, and an optimality system is derived. Consequently, an optimal control can be figured out by solving the optimality system. Some examples of the optimal control are given. Finally, the influence of some factors on the effectiveness of an optimal control is examined through computer experiments. These findings help organizations to work out policies of defending against APTs.

uP1VGJb4.title: Diagnosability of optical multi-mesh hypercube networks under the comparison diagnosis model
uP1VGJb4.abstract: Diagnosability of a multiprocessor system is one important study topic in the parallel processing area. As a family of promising optical interconnection topologies for massively parallel computers, the optical multi-mesh hypercube OMMH networks integrate positive features of both hypercube and mesh topologies and circumvent the lack of scalability of hypercubes and the large diameter of meshes. This paper studies an l, m, n-OMMH network and, proves that its diagnosability under the comparison diagnosis model is n+4 for l≥5, m≥5, n≥3.

g3TiHpo6.title: Global asymptotic stability in a class of Putnam-type equations
g3TiHpo6.abstract: In this paper, we initiate the study of a class of Putnam-type equation of the formxn+1=A1xn+A2xn-1+A3xn-2xn-3+A4B1xnxn-1+B2xn-2+B3xn-3+B4,n=0,1,2,..., where A1, A2, A3, A4, B1, B2, B3, B4 are positive constants with A1+A2+A3+A4=B1+B2+B3+B4, x-3, x-2, x-1, x0 are positive numbers. A sufficient condition is given for the global asymptotic stability of the equilibrium point c=1 of such equations. © 2005 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sJEi7WA8.title: Part-metric and its applications to cyclic discrete dynamic systems
sJEi7WA8.abstract: We adapt the part metric and use it in studying positive solutions of a certain family of discrete dynamic systems. Some examples are presented, and we also compare some results in the literature. © 2011 Wanping Liu et al.

aVd81Rwy.title: System-level probabilistic distributed faulty diagnose based on local area network
aVd81Rwy.abstract: This paper advances a system-level probabilistic distributed fault diagnosis algorithm that can diagnose the faults of the nodes and the links in the LAN or similar systems. The algorithm breaks the limitation which demands that the numbers of faulty nodes must not exceed t(t<n/2 and n is a total of nodes in the network) in a network with the current achievement of research, so this method ia highly practical. This paper also describes the algorithm in detail, proves strictly its validity, computes its right diagnostic probability and analyzes its diagnostic traffic cost. Through running the imitated program, this paper also verifies the changes of right diagnostic probability and diagnostic traffic cost of the algorithm.

0fWjtdRn.title: Embedding even-length cycles in a hexagonal honeycomb mesh
0fWjtdRn.abstract: The existence and construction of cycles of various lengths in an interconnection network are important issues in efficiently executing ring-structured parallel algorithms in such a network. The hexagonal honeycomb mesh (HHM) is regarded as a promising candidate for interconnection networks. In this paper we address the problem of how to embed even-length cycles in an HHM. We prove that an HHM of order t≥3 admits a cycle of length l for each even number l such that l=6 or 10≤l≤6t2-2. We also describe a systematic method for building these cycles.

2R5wP3wC.title: The spread of computer viruses over a reduced scale-free network
2R5wP3wC.abstract: Due to the high dimensionality of an epidemic model of computer viruses over a general scale-free network, it is difficult to make a close study of its dynamics. In particular, it is extremely difficult, if not impossible, to prove the global stability of its viral equilibrium, if any. To overcome this difficulty, we suggest to simplify a general scale-free network by partitioning all of its nodes into two classes: higher-degree nodes and lower-degree nodes, and then equating the degrees of all higher-degree nodes and all lower-degree nodes, respectively, yielding a reduced scale-free network. We then propose an epidemic model of computer viruses over a reduced scale-free network. A theoretical analysis reveals that the proposed model is bound to have a globally stable viral equilibrium, implying that any attempt to eradicate network viruses would prove unavailing. As a result, the next best thing we can do is to restrain virus prevalence. Based on an analysis of the impact of different model parameters on virus prevalence, some practicable measures are recommended to contain virus spreading. The work in this paper adequately justifies the idea of reduced scale-free networks. ? 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

QR7rSw7j.title: An epidemic model of computer viruses with vaccination and generalized nonlinear incidence rate
QR7rSw7j.abstract: This paper aims to explore the influence of vaccination on the diffusion of computer viruses under more reasonable assumptions. By incorporating a vaccination probability in the SIRS model with generalized nonlinear incidence rate, a novel epidemic model of computer viruses is established. A thorough analysis of this model shows that, depending on the value of the basic reproduction number, either the virus-free equilibrium or the endemic equilibrium is globally asymptotically stable. Simulation results not only justify the proposed model, but also demonstrate the effectiveness of vaccination. Based on a parameter analysis for the model, some effective strategies for inhibiting the virus prevalence are posed.

Z8hks80d.title: Maximum induced subgraph of a recursive circulant
Z8hks80d.abstract: The recursive circulant RC(2n, 4) enjoys several attractive topological properties. Let max_εG(m) denote the maximum number of edges in a subgraph of graph G induced by m nodes. In this paper, we show that max_εRC(2n, 4)(m) = Σi=0r(Pi/2 + i)2pi. where p0 p1 ... pr are nonnegative integers defined by m = Σi=0r 2Pi . We then apply this formula to find the bisection width of RC(2n,4). The conclusion shows that, as n-dimensional cube. RC(2n, 4) enjoys a linear bisection width.

crGvXpmD.title: A novel optical folded cube
crGvXpmD.abstract: Optical networks are a class of promising alternative to electrical networks, alleviating complexity problems of electrical implementation and providing better performance. It is crucial to introduce and study new topologies suited to optical communication. This paper proposes a class of optical network architectures named as enhanced folded cubes. The basic properties, including the diameter, connectivity and fault tolerance of the proposed networks are determined, which are remarkably superior to those of their traditional folded cube counterparts. © 2013 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

3iAVzM2l.title: Global exponential periodicity of a class of bidirectional associative memory networks with finite distributed delays
3iAVzM2l.abstract: In this paper, we study the periodic oscillatory behavior of a class of bidirectional associative memory (BAM) networks with finite distributed delays. A set of criteria are proposed for determining global exponential periodicity of the proposed BAM networks, which assume neither differentiability nor monotonicity of the activation function of each neuron. In addition, our criteria are easily checkable.

bpdJG9YM.title: A novel fault tolerance measure of interconnection multiprocessor systems
bpdJG9YM.abstract: Certain nodes cannot be faulty at the same time which can better reflect fault patterns in a real system than the existing ones. The determination of the size of a g-neighborhoods (i. e., a neighborhood of a set of g nodes) in a given graph is essential to analyze the fault tolerance of multiprocessor systems. In this paper, we present a novel fault tolerance measure for hypermesh based on the conditional components, proving the bounds of the neighborhoods of the conditional components and the other results related to fault tolerance. Our study results show that the originally corresponding results tend to underestimate resilience of interconnection multiprocessor systems. © 2012 Binary Information Press.

ZLW92OYx.title: Inherent fault tolerance analysis for a class of multi-layer neural networks with weight deviations
ZLW92OYx.abstract: The general formula of computing the deviation of the output of a multilayer neural network (MLNN) with respect to the deviations of its input and of its weights is presented. The upper bound of the deviation propagation from level to level is well estimated with certain probability. Based on this, one can analyze the relation between the topological structure of an MLNN and its fault tolerance property, which can be used to correctly design fault tolerant MLNNs

Wls5zOfB.title: cis,cis-[(bpy)2RuVO]2O4+ catalyzes water oxidation formally via in situ generation of radicaloid RuIV-O*.
Wls5zOfB.abstract: The mechanism of the catalytic oxidation of water by cis,cis-[(bpy)(2)Ru(OH(2))](2)O(4+) to give molecular dioxygen was investigated using Density Functional Theory (DFT). A series of four oxidation and four deprotonation events generate the catalytically competent species cis,cis-[(bpy)(2)Ru(V)O](2)O(4+), which breaks the H-OH bond homolytically at the rate determining transition state to give a hydroperoxo intermediate. Our calculations predict a rate determining activation barrier of 25.9 kcal/mol in solution phase, which is in reasonable agreement with the previously reported experimental estimate of 18.7-23.3 kcal/mol. A number of plausible coupling schemes of the two metal sites including strong coupling, weak ferromagnetic and weak antiferromagnetic coupling have been considered. In addition, both high-spin and low-spin states at each of the Ru(V)-d(3) centers were explored and we found that the high-spin states play an important mechanistic role. Our calculations suggest that cis,cis-[(bpy)(2)Ru(V)O](2)O(4+) performs formally an intramolecular ligand-to-metal charge transfer when reacting with water to formally give a cis,cis-[(bpy)(2)Ru(IV)O*](2)O(4+) complex. We propose that the key characteristic of the diruthenium catalyst that allows it to accomplish the most difficult first two oxidations of the overall four-electron redox reaction is directly associated with this in situ generation of two radicaloid oxo moieties that promote the water splitting reaction. A proton coupled metal-to-metal charge transfer follows to yield a Ru(V)/Ru(III) peroxo/aqua mixed valence complex, which performs the third redox reaction to give the superoxo/aqua complex. Finally, intersystem crossing to a ferromagnetically coupled Ru(IV)/Ru(III) superoxo/aqua species is predicted, which will then promote the last redox event to release triplet dioxygen as the final product. A number of key features of the computed mechanism are explored in detail to derive a conceptual understanding of the catalytic mechanism.

EBS9Fz91.title: A computer virus model with graded cure rates
EBS9Fz91.abstract: A dynamical model characterizing the spread of computer viruses over the Internet is established, in which two assumptions are imposed: (1) a computer possesses infectivity once it is infected, and (2) latent computers have a lower cure rate than seizing computers. The qualitative properties of this model are fully studied. First, the basic reproduction number, R0, for this model is determined. Second, by introducing appropriate Lyapunov functions, it is proved that the virus-free equilibrium is globally asymptotically stable if R0≤1, whereas the viral equilibrium is globally asymptotically stable if 1< R0≤4. Next, the sensitivity analysis of R0 to three system parameters is conducted, and the dependence of R0 on the remaining system parameters is investigated. On this basis, a set of policies is recommended for eradicating viruses spreading across the Internet effectively. © 2012 Published by Elsevier Ltd.

2dJU3uXC.title: Maximizing the overall profit of a word-of-mouth marketing campaign: A modeling study.
2dJU3uXC.abstract: As compared to the traditional advertising, the word-of-mouth (WOM) communications have striking advantages such as significantly lower cost and rapid delivery; this is especially the case with the popularity of online social networks. This paper addresses the issue of maximizing the overall profit of a WOM marketing campaign. A marketing process with both positive and negative WOM is modeled as a dynamical model knwn as the SIPNS model, and the profit maximization problem is modeled as a constrained optimization problem. The influence of different factors on the dynamics of the SIPNS model is revealed experimentally. Also, the impact of different factors on the expected overall profit of a WOM marketing campaign is uncovered experimentally. On this basis, some promotion strategies are suggested. To our knowledge, this is the first time a WOM marketing campaign is treated this way.

6cCtWj2K.title: Implementing duplex crossed cube communication patterns on optical linear arrays
6cCtWj2K.abstract: Crossed cubes are a class of promising parallel communication patterns. This paper addresses the issue of how to implement a half-duplex or full-duplex crossed cube on a WDM optical network with linear array topology. For either of these two communication patterns, a routing scheme, that is an embedding scheme, is proposed, and a wavelength assignment scheme under the embedding scheme is designed. The number of required wavelengths under the embedding scheme is shown to attain the minimum. © 2013 Elsevier GmbH. All rights reserved.

SmziFTrO.title: Global behavior of two higher-order symmetric difference equations
SmziFTrO.abstract: Motivated by papers [3, 5] here we investigate the global asymptotic stability for positive solutions of the symmetric difference equation yn = (yn-k r-kyn-l r-lyn-m r + yn-k r + yn-l r + yn-m r)/(yn-k ryn-l r + yn-k r - kyn-m r + yn-l r-lyn-m r+ 1), where 1 ≤ k < l < m and r ε (0,1], as well as of the somewhat simpler one yn = (yn-k r + yn-l r)/(1 + yn-k r - kyn-l r), where 1 ≤ k < l and r ε (0, 1]. Our main results extend the main results in [3, 5], where the cases when r = 1 were studied.

i2HysrMu.title: The effect of network topology on the spread of computer viruses: a modelling study.
i2HysrMu.abstract: This paper is intended to investigate the effect of network topology on the spread of computer viruses in the presence of removable storage media. For that purpose, a novel network-based computer virus spreading model is proposed. Both theoretically and experimentally, it is shown that, under proper conditions, viruses on a scale-free network would tend to extinction. Experimental results show that either smaller maximum node degree or larger power-law exponent is conducive to the containment of virus spreading. To our knowledge, this is the first time the effect of network topology on virus spreading is investigated in this context.
